titleStmt.title: Example of a Spiritual Contagion Effect Previous Research

affiliation.orgName: Department of Organizational Behaviour and Human Resource Management

address.settlement: George Newman https://orcid.org/, Natalie O. Fedotova https://orcid.org

analytic.title: Example of a Spiritual Contagion Effect Previous Research

biblStruct.note: Accepted Article This article has been accepted for publication and undergone full peer review but has not been through the copyediting, typesetting, pagination and proofreading process which may lead to differences between this version and the Version of Record. Please cite this article as doi: 10.1002/jcpy.1331

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: Contagion is the belief that an entity's invisible or essential qualities can be transferred to a target. Researchers studying contagion have often distinguished between physical contagion (the perceived transfer of germs, toxins, and pathogens) and spiritual contagion (the perceived transfer of metaphysical properties such as spirits, essence, and moral characteristics). While sensitivity to physical contagion is a component of several existing scales, to date, there are no scales that measure sensitivity to spiritual contagion. Here, we develop and validate a measure of Spiritual Contagion Sensitivity (SCS), which considers positive, negative, and neutral aspects of spiritual contagion. We demonstrate discriminant validity from existing measures of physical contagion sensitivity, such as perceived vulnerability to disease and disgust sensitivity (Study 1). We demonstrate construct validity by showing the correlation between SCS and a variety of published findings in the literature for which spiritual contagion beliefs have been hypothesized to play a role (Study 2). Finally, we demonstrate predictive utility of the SCS scale by showing significant moderation of spiritual contagion effects from the literature (Studies 3A-3C).

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Many of the things that can harm us, such as germs or toxins, are invisible to the naked eye. A belief in contagion-the notion that an entity's invisible or essential qualities can be transferred to a target-serves to track and avoid such contaminants (Nemeroff & Rozin, 1994;Rozin et al., 1986;Rozin & Nemeroff, 2002). However, as was documented over 100 years ago (Frazer, 1936(Frazer, /2013Mauss, 1902Mauss, /2001Tylor, 1871), it is common for contagion beliefs to arise in contexts that do not immediately involve harmful microbes or toxins. For example, in several cultures it was believed that a person's physical residues (e.g., hair, fingernail clipping) contained their essence (Frazer, 1922(Frazer, /1990. People in many cultures endorse the belief that one may acquire the properties of the animals or materials they ingest (Nemeroff & Rozin, 1989). Even North-American undergraduates refuse to wear a sweater worn by a "creepy person" because the sweater itself is seen as tainted and creepy (Nemeroff & Rozin, 1994).

Contagion beliefs involve four central components: a source, a target, a contaminant (i.e., the thing or property that is transferred from the source to the target), and a means of contamination. In this paper, we focus on a distinction between sensitivities to different types of contaminants. Specifically, we distinguish between sensitivities to physical contagion and sensitivities to spiritual contagion (Huang et al., 2017;Nemeroff & Rozin, 1994).

Physical contagion sensitivity is sensitivity to the transfer of physical contaminants (e.g., pathogens, germs, toxins, and other harmful, disgusting, or aversive agents; Nemeroff & Rozin, 1994). People may be sensitive to the transfer of these contaminants even when they are aware that there is little potential for harm. For example, Rozin et al. (1986) showed that Americans rejected orange juice that had been in brief contact with a dead, sterilized cockroach, even though they understood that the drink was safe to consume.

div.head: Accepted Article
div.p: SPIRITUAL CONTAGION SENSITIVITY 4 In contrast, spiritual contagion sensitivity is sensitivity to the transfer of metaphysical contaminants (e.g., spirits, essence, abilities, the moral characteristics of a source). For example, adults refuse to try on a sweater if they believe that it once belonged to a serial killer or Adolf Hitler (Rozin et al., 1986). In such cases, the contaminant is not anything physical that could potentially cause harm; rather, the contaminant is something immaterial in nature-the person's immoral character, or spiritual "cooties." Spiritual contagion sensitivity does not merely arise from participants' desires to communicate their own moral beliefs about the source in question.
For example, people prefer to wear gloves when handling a morally tainted object, even if they would so in private (Fedotova & Rozin, 2013).

Beyond the nature of the contaminant, a second important distinction between physical and spiritual contagion is the valence of the contaminant. Physical contagion sensitivity involves primarily negative contaminants-e.g., things that are harmful or disgusting. By contrast, spiritual contagion sensitivity involves properties that may be negative (e.g., Hitler's essence), positive (e.g., my favorite celebrity's essence), or neutral (e.g., an ancestor's essence).

Although one may consider the means of contamination (i.e., presence or absence of physical contact) to be the key distinction between physical and spiritual contagion, in our view, it is not. For example, if an individual avoids physical contact with someone who has a sexually transmitted disease, they may be concerned about physical contagion (transfer of the pathogen) or spiritual contagion (transfer of perceived immorality). In such cases, the means of contamination does not differentiate between physical and spiritual contagion, whereas the nature of the contaminant does differentiate between them.

div.head: Spiritual Versus Physical Contagion: A Mismatch Between Phenomena and Measures
div.p: In the existing literature, there are several scales that measure physical contagion sensitivity, such as the Perceived Vulnerability to Disease scale (Duncan et al., 2009)

div.head: Accepted Article
div.p: Vancouver Obsessional Compulsive Inventory, Contamination subscale (Thordarson et al., 2004). Additionally, the Disgust Scale (Haidt et al., 1994;Olatunji et al., 2007;Rozin et al., 1984) include items which measure physical contagion beliefs (e.g., "Even if I was hungry, I
would not drink a bowl of my favorite soup if it had been stirred by a used but thoroughly washed flyswatter").

To date, however, there are no measures of spiritual contagion sensitivity (Nemeroff et al., 2020, p. 960). This is notable, because much of the research in consumer behavior has focused on phenomena related to spiritual contagion, rather than physical contagion. Some prominent examples of spiritual contagion effects are listed in Table 1.

div.head: Some Examples of Spiritual Contagion Effects
div.p: It is important to note that physical and spiritual contagion are theoretically related, as spiritual contagion beliefs are hypothesized to derive from mechanisms used for tracking the spread of actual disease contaminants (Nemeroff & Rozin, 1994;Rozin et al., 2009). Consistent with this notion, Chapman et al. (2009) find that oral disgust and moral disgust evoke similar facial motor activity, and Chan et al. (2014) show that moral violations can reduce oral consumption.

In the absence of a dedicated measure of spiritual contagion sensitivity, previous research relied on measures of physical contagion sensitivity when assessing individual differences in spiritual contagion effects. For example, Hingston et al. (2017) and Newman and Bloom (2014) adapted and used two items from the Disgust Scale (Olatunji et al., 2007) and four items from the Perceived Vulnerability to Disease scale (Duncan et al., 2009) to measure "contagion sensitivity." Likewise, Newman et al. (2011) and Newman and Dhar (2014) used the same two items from the Disgust Scale in their measure of "contagion sensitivity." Nonetheless, given that much of the research on contagion within consumer behavior focuses on spiritual contagion phenomena, we argue that there is a need for a more targeted measure of spiritual contagion sensitivity (hereafter, SCS).

Beyond providing greater empirical precision, developing a measure of SCS addresses several important theoretical issues. First, while it has been hypothesized that physical and spiritual contagion are distinct psychological constructs, to date, no research has directly tested this claim. Second, existing measures of physical contagion sensitivity (hereafter, PCS) only measure sensitivity to negative contaminants and are thus ill-suited to measure sensitivity to negative, positive, or neutral spiritual contagion. Finally, developing a reliable measure of SCS provides a means of assessing whether various consumer behavior phenomena are, in fact, related to spiritual contagion. In other words, in cases where researchers hypothesize that

div.head: Accepted Article
div.p: SPIRITUAL CONTAGION SENSITIVITY 7 spiritual contagion beliefs explain various behavioral results, a reliable measure of SCS provides a straightforward means of empirically testing those claims.

div.head: Study 1
div.p: Study 1 validates the three-factor structure of our SCS scale (sensitivities to negative, neutral, and positive spiritual contagion) and demonstrates the scale's discriminant validity by distinguishing it from existing measures of PCS.

div.head: The SCS Scale
div.p: The SCS scale was developed over the course of a decade. Specifically, the scale items were developed as part of the third author's dissertation, under the guidance of the last author (Fedotova & Rozin, 2013). The items were subjected to extensive pilot testing, multiple iterations of revisions, and consultation with several experts in the field.

The result is a 12-item scale (see Table 2). The scale asks respondents to rate on a series of 7-point Likert scales the extent to which they agree or disagree with four statements about negative spiritual contagion (e.g., "I could never live on a piece of land where someone was tortured and killed, even if I built a brand-new house"), four statements about positive spiritual contagion (e.g., "I would be excited to try on a jacket that was worn by my favorite musician, even if I could not tell other people about it"), and four statements about neutral spiritual contagion (e.g., "I believe that family heirlooms, such as jewelry, are imbued with the spirits of the people they once belonged to").

div.head: Study Procedure
div.p: Using the online platform Prolific (Palan & Schitter, 2018), we recruited 500 U.S. residents (Mage = 35.7, 51% female) to participate in Study 1. All participants completed four scales: the SCS (described above), Perceived Vulnerability to Disease (hereafter, PVD; Duncan Accepted Article SPIRITUAL CONTAGION SENSITIVITY 8 et al., 2009), Part I of the Disgust Scale-Revised (hereafter, DS-R; Olatunji et al., 2007), and the contamination subscale of the Vancouver Obsessional Compulsive Inventory (hereafter, VOCI-CTN; Thordarson et al., 2004). We adapted the original scales by dropping outdated items and changing the scales to 7-point scales (1 = Strongly Disagree, 7 = Strongly Agree). All scale items are reported in Section A of the Methodological Details Appendix (hereafter, MDA).

Participants responded to a total of 48 items, which were presented one per item page, in a completely randomized order. Afterwards, participants provided demographic information (age, gender, political ideology, and education). Analyses on SCS by demographic variables are presented in the MDA, Section N.

div.head: Results
div.p: We confirmed that our 12-item scale of SCS consists of the positive, negative, and neutral components by conducting (a) parallel analysis, (b) exploratory factor analysis (EFA), and (c) confirmatory factor analyses (CFA). First, a parallel analysis (Dinno, 2018;Horn, 1965;Kim, 2022b) suggested retention of three factors as expected (see the MDA, Figure B1). Next, we used CEFA program (Browne et al., 2010) to conduct an exploratory factor analysis, extracting three factors with Maximum Wishart Likelihood factor extraction method and Promax rotation method. Results of this EFA (Table 2) show that items intended to capture positive, negative, and neutral spiritual contagion components do indeed load on their respective factors (all main factor loadings > 0.4). A follow-up confirmatory factor analysis using structural equation modeling showed that the model of SCS consisting of the three components (negative, positive, and neutral) had a good fit, with each indicator having an acceptable loading for their respective component; χ 2 (51) = 84.7, RMSEA = 0.036, CFI = 0.981, TLI = 0.976, SRMR = .0387 (see the MDA, Section C). Note. We extracted three factors using Maximum Wishart Likelihood factor extraction and a Promax rotation method. Factor loadings for items' intended factor (subscale) are in bold. a These items were reverse-coded.

div.head: Accepted Article
div.p: We next computed correlation and reliability coefficients for all four scales examined in this study. Table 3 shows each scale's reliability coefficient (Cronbach's alpha) along the diagonal, and the correlation between each column and each row scale below the diagonal.

Following the logic of Raghunathan and Chandrasekaran (2021), we compared reliability coefficients with correlation (validity) coefficients. To the extent that the SCS scale is related to the measures of physical contagion sensitivity, and yet, sufficiently different from them, the correlation (validity) coefficients should be significant but lower than the reliability coefficients.
Indeed, this is what we find: while the correlation coefficients were all significant (p < .012) and

div.head: Accepted Article
div.p: SPIRITUAL CONTAGION SENSITIVITY 10 ranged from r = .11 to r = .49, they were all lower than the reliability coefficients, which ranged from α = .73 to .88. In other words, the SCS items were more correlated with one another than they were with the existing measures of PCS. Note. Each scale's Cronbach's alpha is shown along the diagonal in parentheses, and correlations between the column and row scale scores are shown below the diagonal. *** p < .001; * p < .05

We further assessed discriminant validity of the SCS scale by using two common methods: Fornell and Larcker (1981) method and heterotrait-monotrait (HTMT) method (Henseler et al., 2015). Results of these analyses also supported discriminant validity of the SCS scale; see the MDA, Section D.

div.head: Discussion
div.p: Results from the parallel analysis, EFA, and CFA all converge to support the three-factor structure of the 12-item SCS scale (i.e., negative, positive, and neutral SCS). More importantly, results from the correlation and discriminant validity analyses suggest that SCS is related to, yet distinct from, the physical contagion sensitivity constructs.

div.head: Study 2
div.p: The main objective of Study 2 was to provide evidence of construct validity. To assess construct validity, we examined the correlation between scores on the SCS scale and 10 previously identified effects from the consumer literature for which spiritual contagion beliefs have been hypothesized to play a role. The 10 previously published findings are listed in Table 4.

For each finding, we consulted the original research article, selected a vignette that operationalized the finding, and adapted the measure for our study. When using the original vignette verbatim was not feasible, we constructed a new vignette, drawing inspiration from the original materials. For example, for the ability contagion construct (Kramer & Block, 2014), we could not manipulate-for our online participants-physically touching a study guide used by the previous high-or low-performing participant. We thus asked participants to imagine a scenario in which they were taking a difficult course and were choosing to receive either handwritten notes (physical touch) or an electronic copy of the same notes (no physical touch) from a friend who did well in the course. All 10 vignettes are reported in the MDA, Section E.

div.head: Method
div.p: From the online platform Prolific, we recruited 501 U.S. residents (Mage = 32.9, 49% female) to participate in Study 2. All participants began the study by completing the 10 vignettes in a random order (each was shown on a separate page). Participants then completed the 12-item SCS scale and the 13-item Disgust Scale (all 25 items in a random order). We measured disgust sensitivity along with SCS because it was the construct most closely related to SCS in Study 1.

This enabled us to compare the predictive utility of the SCS scale with that of the 13-item Disgust Scale as well as the two items from the Disgust Scale, which have been used in previous research to measure general "contagion sensitivity" (Newman & Dhar, 2014). After completing

div.head: Accepted Article
div.p: the SCS and Disgust Scale, participants provided demographic information (age, gender, political ideology, and education).

div.head: Results
div.p: To test whether SCS significantly correlates with the 10 published findings, we first created a composite score of the 10 vignettes by taking the following steps. For each vignette, we created a vignette score by recoding participants' responses such that higher ratings indicated attitudes, beliefs, or behaviors consistent with a greater sensitivity to spiritual contagion (e.g., reluctance to receive an organ transplant from a murderer or preference for products made in the original factory). Eight of the 10 vignettes were coded in this manner. For two vignettes measured with multiple items (i.e., preference for earlier serial numbers [Smith et al., 2016] and perceived attractiveness of handmade products [Fuchs et al., 2015]), the mean rating across the items (computed within-participant) served as the vignette score. Next, we computed the z-score for each of the 10 vignette scores and computed the mean of these 10 z-scores for each participant (hereafter, the composite score).

We then correlated the composite score with SCS. As hypothesized, the composite score of the 10 vignettes were significantly and positively correlated with the mean rating on the SCS scale: r(499) = .19, p < .001 (see the MDA, Figure F1). Thus, consumers who scored higher on our SCS scale did indeed think and behave in ways that suggest greater sensitivity to spiritual contagion. We then compared SCS with disgust sensitivity in terms of the strength of their correlation with the composite score of the 10 vignettes. The correlation between disgust sensitivity and the composite score, though significant, was much weaker than that between SCS and the composite score-only about half the size: r(499) = .10, p = .028. Moreover, the two correlations (.19 and .10) were significantly different from each other, Williams's t(498) = -2.2, p = .031 (Chen & Popovich, 2002;Kim, 2022b;Steiger, 1980). Thus, although SCS and disgust

div.head: Accepted Article
div.p: SPIRITUAL CONTAGION SENSITIVITY 13 sensitivity both correlated with previously identified spiritual contagion phenomena, SCS explained spiritual contagion effects to a greater extent than disgust sensitivity.

div.head: Correlation Between SCS and Each of the 10 Vignettes
div.p: We further examined construct validity of the SCS scale and its three subscales by correlating them with each of the 10 vignette scores individually. The 10 correlation coefficients along with the associated p-values are listed in Table 4. These analyses revealed that SCS was significantly correlated in the expected direction with five of the 10 vignettes: moral contagion regarding organ transplants (Hood et al., 2011), meaning attached to historical artifacts (Grayson & Martinec, 2004), preference for products from the original source of production (Newman & Dhar, 2014), ability contagion (Kramer & Block, 2014), and perceived attractiveness of handmade products (Fuchs et al., 2015); see the MDA, Section G, for further discussion of why some of these measures may have failed to show significant correlations.

Additionally, when we examine the three subscales and compare their predictive utility against the 2-item measure of contagion sensitivity and the Disgust Scale, we see that in most cases, the appropriate subscale (based on valence) showed the highest correlation with the phenomenon of interest (see Note in Table 4). Note. Correlations in this table shows that each of the three, 4-item subscales of SCS can be a better predictor for spiritual contagion phenomena of different valences than either the 2-item measure of contagion sensitivity or the Disgust Scale (the last two columns of this table). For example, perceived attractiveness of handmade products (a positive spiritual contagion phenomenon) is better predicted by (i.e., shows a stronger correlation with) the positive subscale of SCS (r = .17) than either the 2-item measure of contagion sensitivity (r = .06) or the Disgust Scale (r = .06), Williams's t-test ps < .05. Such results demonstrate the utility of more targeted measures of sensitivity to spiritual contagion, namely, the subscales measuring sensitivity to positive, negative, and neutral spiritual contagion.

div.head: Discussion
div.p: Results from Study 2 provide evidence for construct validity of SCS. The correlation analyses indicate that SCS is mostly correlated in the expected direction with spiritual contagion effects documented in the literature.

div.head: Development of a Short Form of the Scale
div.p: We developed a short-form (3-item) version of the scale that may be more readily adopted by researchers and present less demands for participants. Following Stanton et al. (2002), we reduced the length of our scale by considering the 12 items' external, internal, and judgmental qualities (in the order of decreasing importance). The scale reduction procedure detailed in the MDA, Section H, resulted in the short form of the scale consisting of the three items in Table 5.

div.head: Table 5
div.p: Spiritual Contagion Sensitivity Scale, Short Form # Item 1 I would be fine drinking from a glass that was previously used by a Nazi, as long as it was sterilized. (R) 2 I would be excited to touch a piece of scientific equipment if I knew that it had been used to make a famous discovery.
3 The notion that objects can absorb the "essence" of certain people seems silly to me. (R)

Note. Participants answered all three items above in a randomized order on a 7-point scale (1 = Strongly Disagree, 7 = Strongly Agree). Items 1 and 3 were reverse-coded. An index of spiritual contagion sensitivity was computed by averaging the ratings across the three items.

div.head: Overview of Studies 3A-3C
div.p: We conducted Studies 3A-3C with two goals in mind: (1) to further demonstrate predictive utility of the SCS scale using an alternative method and (2) to compare the performance of our SCS scale (short-form) with that of the two items frequently used in the

div.head: Accepted Article
div.p: SPIRITUAL CONTAGION SENSITIVITY 16 literature to measure contagion sensitivity. To achieve these goals, we conducted three studies (3A-3C) testing whether the SCS (short-form) moderates three different spiritual contagion effects. The effects that we selected were the three highest-correlated effects identified in Study 2: moral contagion regarding an organ transplant from a murderer (Study 3A), meaning attached to historical artifacts (Study 3B), and preference for products from the original source of production (Study 3C). Further, these three phenomena respectively provided examples of negative spiritual contagion (immoral essence), neutral spiritual contagion (unspecified historical events), and positive spiritual contagion (luxury brand essence).
In each of the three studies, we replicated the basic effect using the materials adapted from the original papers (Grayson & Martinec, 2004;Hood et al., 2011;Newman & Dhar, 2014).

We additionally measured two moderator variables: SCS (short-form) and two items taken from the Disgust Scale and used in previous research to measure "contagion sensitivity" (hereafter, the 2-item measure; Newman & Dhar, 2014;Olatunji et al., 2007). The two items were as follows:

(1) "Even if I was hungry, I would not drink a bowl of my favorite soup if it had been stirred by a used but thoroughly washed flyswatter"; (2) "It would bother me to sleep in a nice hotel room if I knew that a man had died of a heart attack in that room the night before." These two items were measured on the same 7-point scale as the SCS. Our aim was to test whether the SCS
(short-form) shows stronger moderations of spiritual contagion effects (i.e., stronger interaction effects), as compared with the 2-item measure from the literature.

div.head: Study 3A
div.p: A total of 400 U.S. residents (Mage = 38, 49% female) were recruited from Prolific to participate in Study 3A. All participants began the study by imagining that they had a severe heart disease and were waiting for a donor heart for a heart-transplant (see the MDA, Figure I1).

div.head: Accepted Article
div.p: After 14 months of waiting, the doctor told them they could receive a heart transplant from someone young and in good health that died recently. At this point, participants were randomly assigned to one of two conditions (Donor: Murderer vs. Volunteer) designed to produce a moral contagion effect (Hood et al., 2011). In the Murderer condition, the donor "murdered their spouse and committed suicide," whereas in the Volunteer condition, the donor "volunteered often, helping people… [and] died in a car accident."

Participants rated how happy they would be to receive a heart transplant from the donor on an 11-point scale (0 = Not Very, 10 = Very). Participants then completed the short form of our SCS scale (3 items) and the 2-item measure of "contagion sensitivity" used in previous research (Newman & Dhar, 2014); the order of these five items was randomized for each participant.
Participants concluded the study by providing demographic information.

div.head: Study 3B
div.p: A total of 401 U.S. residents (Mage = 36; 50% female) were recruited from Prolific to participate in Study 3B. All participants began the study by reading that historical museums consider displaying replicas instead of original objects for safety and preservation concerns (see the MDA, Figure I2). Participants were then randomly assigned to one of two conditions (Replica vs. Original). In the Replica [Original] condition, participants were presented with the question, "If a history museum contained only identical replica objects (not originals) [original objects (not replicas)], how likely would you be to visit that museum?" They answered the question on a 7-point scale (1 = Not at all, 7 = Very likely), and these ratings served as the dependent measure of the study. As in Study 3A, all participants subsequently answered the five moderator items (three items of SCS short-form and the 2-item measure in previous research) in a randomized order and provided demographic information.

div.head: Study 3C
div.p: A total of 400 U.S. residents (Mage = 36, 49% female) were recruited from Prolific to participate in Study 3C. All participants began the study by reading about Godiva Chocolatier which was "originally founded in Belgium, over 90 years ago … [and] has chocolate factories in several different locations around the world" (see the MDA, Figure I3). They then saw an image of a box of chocolate made by the company and priced at $32.
At this point, participants were randomly assigned to one of two conditions (Newer vs.
Original Factory). In the Newer Factory condition, participants read that the chocolates were "made in a newer factory, located in Reading, Pennsylvania … [which] was built 10 years ago."
In the Original Factory condition, participants instead read that the chocolates were "made in the original factory, located in Brussels, Belgium … [which] was built over 90 years ago."

Participants then rated the extent to which they would be willing to pay a premium for the box of chocolates (1 = Would not pay a premium, 9 = Would pay a premium) and how much they would be willing to pay for the particular box of chocolates relative to the average box of Godiva chocolates (1 = Substantially less, 9 = Substantially more). The average rating of these two items served as the study's dependent variable: product valuation. All participants subsequently answered the same five moderator items as in Studies 3A and 3B (in a randomized order) and provided demographic information.

div.head: Confirming the Effects Predicted by the Previous Research
div.p: Study 3A. We found a strong moral contagion effect predicted by previous research.
Participants expecting to receive a heart transplant from a murderer were significantly less happy (M = 6.4, SD = 3.1) than those expecting to receive it from a volunteer (M = 9.1, SD = 1.5),

div.head: Accepted Article
div.p: Study 3B. We found a strong preference for original objects over replicas, operationalized as increased likelihood of visiting the museum. Participants reported greater likelihood of visiting the museum when it contained original objects (M = 6.2, SD = 1.1) than when it contained replicas (M = 3.5, SD = 1.7), Welch's t(345) = 18, d = 1.8, p < .001.

Study 3C. We found the factory of origin contagion effect predicted by previous research. Participants valued the chocolates made in the original factory (M = 4.9, SD = 1.9) more than those made in the newer factory (M = 4.2, SD = 1.7), Welch's t(393) = -3.9, d = 0.39, p < .001.

div.head: Moderation of Spiritual Contagion Effects by SCS Short Form and the 2-Item Measure
div.p: Having confirmed the three contagion effects predicted by previous research, we next tested whether each of the effects is indeed stronger among participants who are more sensitive to spiritual contagion than among participants who are less sensitive to spiritual contagion (see Note in Figure 1). At the same time, we also tested whether such moderation effects are stronger with SCS short form scores as the moderator as compared with the 2-item measure scores as the moderator. Specifically, we conducted three separate regressions analyses, one for each study, in which each study's dependent variable (e.g., happiness with heart transplant) is regressed on (1) experimental condition (e.g., 0 = Murderer, 1 = Volunteer), (2) mean-centered score on the 2item measure, (3) mean-centered score on the SCS short form, (4) condition × mean-centered score on the 2-item measure interaction, and (5) condition × mean-centered score on the SCS short form interaction (see Table 6). a The donor of a heart transplant was manipulated to be either a murderer (0) or a volunteer worker (1).

div.head: Accepted Article
div.p: b Scores on the 2-item measure (CS = Contagion Sensitivity) and SCS short form were mean-centered prior to model estimation.
c Product of the binary condition variable (0 vs. 1) and mean-centered score on the 2-item measure (CS).
d Product of the binary condition variable (0 vs. 1) and mean-centered score on the SCS short form.
e The objects in a museum were manipulated to be either replicas (0) or original objects (1).
f The chocolates were manipulated to be made either in a newer factory (0) or in the original factory (1).

As shown in Table 6, the condition × SCS interaction was significant in all studies (p ≤ .030). However, the condition × the 2-item measure interaction was not significant in Studies 3B and 3C, though significant in Study 3A. Moreover, comparing the strengths of the two interactions (Paternoster et al., 1998) after standardizing all variables in each regression model

div.head: Accepted Article
div.p: SPIRITUAL CONTAGION SENSITIVITY 21 revealed that the condition × SCS interaction was significantly or marginally significantly stronger than the condition × the 2-item measure interaction in each of the three studies, Z > 1.60, p < .054 (see the MDA, Section J).

We further examined the nature of the condition × SCS interaction in each of the three studies (see the MDA, Section K). As seen in Figure 1 (Panels A, C, and E), SCS was selectively correlated with responses in the conditions that one would expect, in the directions predicted by theory. Specifically, in Study 3A, SCS was negatively correlated with happiness about receiving a murderer's heart, r(197) = -.49, p < .001, but uncorrelated with happiness about receiving a volunteer's heart, r(199) = -.02, p = .73 ( Figure 1, Panel A). In Study 3B, SCS was positively correlated with wanting to view original historical artifacts, r(198) = .21, p = .003, but uncorrelated with wanting to view replicas, r(199) = -.07, p = .29 ( Figure 1, Panel C). In Study 3C, SCS was positively correlated with valuation of the original-factory product, r(198) = .20, p = .004, but uncorrelated with valuation of the newer-factory product r(198) = -.09, p = .21 ( Figure 1, Panel E).

div.head: Figure 1
div.p: Probing the Moderation of Spiritual Contagion Effects by SCS or the 2-Item Measure Note. In each of the Panels A-F, scores on either moderator measure (SCS Short Form or the 2-item measure) are plotted along the horizontal axis, and scores on the dependent measure are plotted along the vertical axis. Each dot represents a single participant's response, and each line represents the simple linear regression line within the experimental condition. The vertical lines (e.g., those at 2.4 and 7 in Panel A) denote either a Johnson-Neyman point (e.g., 2.4) estimated from a floodlight analysis (Johnson & Neyman, 1936;Kim, 2022a;Spiller et al., 2013) or the observed maximum score on a moderator (e.g., 7). Each region shaded in green between the vertical lines thus represents the region in which participants from two experimental conditions had significantly different scores on the dependent measure.

div.head: General Discussion
div.p: The present studies develop and validate long (12-item) and short (3-item) measures of spiritual contagion sensitivity (SCS). In Study 1, we confirm the three-factor structure of our and (b) show that our SCS scale is a stronger moderator of spiritual contagion effects as compared with the measure of "contagion sensitivity" used in previous research.

One theoretical contribution of the present research is demonstrating that physical and spiritual contagion are distinct psychological constructs. In some cases, these phenomena may overlap, but the SCS scales provide useful means of distinguishing them. For example, adding cream into a meat dish (Nemeroff & Rozin, 1992) may be perceived as either physical or spiritual contagion for people who observe kosher laws. Dairy is a physical substance, but the violation of kosher laws is a moral one. The SCS scales developed here would be useful in examining such cases, because they can more precisely identify which kind of contagion (spiritual vs. not) a consumer is responding to.

Moreover, given that most of the research on contagion within consumer behavior examines spiritual (rather than physical) contagion, the SCS scales provide a means of assessing whether various consumer behavior phenomena are, in fact, related to spiritual contagion. In Studies 2 and 3A-3C, we show that in cases where researchers have hypothesized that spiritual contagion beliefs explain various behavioral results, the SCS scales provide a straightforward means of empirically testing those hypotheses. In addition, the positive, negative, and neutral

div.head: Accepted Article
div.p: subscales of our 12-item scale provide even more targeted measures of spiritual contagion sensitivity, because researchers studying spiritual contagion effects of particular valence(s) can use any (combination) of the subscales to test their specific hypotheses.

In addition to more targeted uses when examining contaminants of different valences, another extension of our work would be to explore the role of spiritual contagion sensitivity in more social psychological phenomena. For example, future research may consider the potential role of SCS in important social issues like intergroup attitudes. Previous research shows that physical contagion sensitivities (i.e., disgust sensitivity and/or perceived vulnerability to disease) predict phenomena such as ethnocentrism (Navarrete & Fessler, 2006), demands for protectionist policies (closing the border regarding disease outbreaks; Kam, 2019), and intuitive disapproval of homosexuals (Inbar et al., 2009). Similarly, intergroup disgust sensitivity predicts negative attitudes towards many outgroups and Islamophobia (Choma et al., 2012;Hodson et al., 2013).

Because SCS is closely linked with physical contagion sensitivity, and SCS can be engaged via both physical contact and any type of metaphysical link (Morales et al., 2018), SCS may be a better predictor of such intergroup attitudes. Moreover, since intergroup attitudes encompass both outgroup avoidance and ingroup attraction (Navarrete & Fessler, 2006), SCS with its negative and positive components may better predict both aspects of intergroup attitudes.

In sum, the current work represents a significant step in development of an instrument designed to measure individual differences in spiritual contagion sensitivity. Scale development is a continuous, collective effort, and additional studies of the psychometric properties of the SCS scales will undoubtedly improve them. In the meantime, we hope that the creation of longand short-form measures of SCS opens the door for several new lines of inquiry.
